Hi German,

I'll go ahead and field this one, and let Ken add any comments if need be.

> My question is what does the text mean by "rather than only at the very
> end"?

A really common problem in Neuro-evolution (and in complexifying genetic
algorithms as a whole) is that genetic structure is sometimes added that
doesn't serve any purpose. This kind of structure can accrue over time and
make the chromosome sizes very large (which increases the number of
dimensions in the search space). To make the evolved networks more
understandable/computationally efficient, some systems simplify the output
of overly complex genetic code at the "end" of evolution. For example, if
neuron A is connected to neuron B by link 1 and also link 2, then the
weights of these two links are summed and the connection is simplified to
one link. This "simplifies" the neural network but doesn't result in a
loss in functionality.

Ken's hypothesis was that if we could somehow avoid adding this kind of
redundant structure in the first place, then the GA search takes place
over a smaller space, and therefore can be more efficient.

Hope that helps.

Joe

-- 

Joseph Reisinger
